elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">A series of new metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) composed of a transition-metal organic acid salt and 2, 5-bis(3-pyridyl)-3,4-diaza-2,4-hexadiene (3-bpdh) was prepared via diffusion in a H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O–MeOH solvent system. The results illustrated that MOFs self-assembly should be achieved by metal-ion potential and building blocks. The loading of MOF microcrystals with titanium dioxide resulted in the composite photocatalyst TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@ZnMOF, which exhibited excellent photodegradation (64%) of the dye methyl blue. Importantly, this approach provides an innovative way of enhancing the photocatalytic effect of MOFs with potential applications as a catalyst support.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A series of new metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) composed of a transition-metal organic acid salt and 2, 5-bis(3-pyridyl)-3,4-diaza-2,4-hexadiene (3-bpdh) was prepared via diffusion in a H2O-MeOH solvent system. The results illustrated that MOFs self-assembly should be achieved by metal-ion potential and building blocks. The loading of MOF microcrystals with titanium dioxide resulted in the composite photocatalyst TiO2@ZnMOF, which exhibited excellent photodegradation (64%) of the dye methyl blue. Importantly, this approach provides an innovative way of enhancing the photocatalytic effect of MOFs with potential applications as a catalyst support.

Highlights

   ⋅ Synthesis and structure of a series of new metal-organic frameworks   ⋅ MOFs should be achieved by metal-ion potential and building blocks.   ⋅ Enhancing the photocatalytic effect of the dye methyl blue a catalyst support

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Synthesis and structure of a series of new metal–organic frameworks</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">MOFs should be achieved by metal-ion potential and building blocks.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Enhancing the photocatalytic effect of the dye methyl blue a catalyst support</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are compounds consisting of metal ions linked together by organic bridging ligands. They represent a new field between molecular coordination chemistry and material science and have attracted extensive attention in recent years. Research on MOFs is expanding rapidly because of their novel structural topologies and promising properties related to gas storage , gas separation , catalysis , chemical sensing , magnetism , ion exchange , fluorescence, and ferroelectricity . The strategies used to synthesize MOFs offer many possibilities for their structural design, enabling the synthesis of complex structures with extensive potential functionalities. The properties of MOFs can be tailored by variation of both inorganic metal centers and organic linkers . Thus far, the most widely studied MOFs are based on pure carboxylate ligands and are constructed from a certain number of distinct building blocks. Apart from carboxylate ligands, those with nitrogen-containing heterocycles such as pyridines, pyrazoles, and tetrazoles have been reported to exhibit promising coordination chemistry for the synthesis of MOFs when combined with carboxylate groups . The literature contains numerous reports of MOFs prepared with different metal ions and pyridine ligands . As demonstrated in these studies, these long, conjugated, rigid ligands are capable of coordinating transition-metal centers with their terminal pyridyl nitrogen donors to generate novel MOFs. These building blocks with relative orientations of the nitrogen donors could lead to the construction of a series of new MOFs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and structure of a series of new metal-organic frameworks

MOFs should be achieved by metal-ion potential and building blocks.

Enhancing the photocatalytic effect of the dye methyl blue a catalyst support

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are compounds consisting of metal ions linked together by organic bridging ligands. They represent a new field between molecular coordination chemistry and material science and have attracted extensive attention in recent years. Research on MOFs is expanding rapidly because of their novel structural topologies and promising properties related to gas storage , gas separation , catalysis , chemical sensing , magnetism , ion exchange , fluorescence, and ferroelectricity . The strategies used to synthesize MOFs offer many possibilities for their structural design, enabling the synthesis of complex structures with extensive potential functionalities. The properties of MOFs can be tailored by variation of both inorganic metal centers and organic linkers . Thus far, the most widely studied MOFs are based on pure carboxylate ligands and are constructed from a certain number of distinct building blocks. Apart from carboxylate ligands, those with nitrogen-containing heterocycles such as pyridines, pyrazoles, and tetrazoles have been reported to exhibit promising coordination chemistry for the synthesis of MOFs when combined with carboxylate groups . The literature contains numerous reports of MOFs prepared with different metal ions and pyridine ligands . As demonstrated in these studies, these long, conjugated, rigid ligands are capable of coordinating transition-metal centers with their terminal pyridyl nitrogen donors to generate novel MOFs. These building blocks with relative orientations of the nitrogen donors could lead to the construction of a series of new MOFs.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Nanotechnology emerged as a new field in the 1980s and has since been a subject of extensive research interest. Self-assembly is the autonomous organization of components into patterns or structures without human intervention. In the MOF synthesis process, the molecules connect with each other through noncovalent bonds into a structurally stable molecular aggregate. Whitesides and Grzybowski  have speculated that such self-assembly will be an essential part of nanotechnology. The application of nanotechnology to the synthesis of MOFs enables the preparation of nanocrystalline materials with superior properties. Liu and Tang  have synthesized multifunctional nanoparticle@MOFs, that are core–shell nanostructures in which nanoparticles serve as the core and MOFs as the shell. Dhakshinamoorthy and Garcia's review  on catalysis by metal nanoparticles embedded in MOFs was organized according to the embedded metal and included Pd, Au, Ru, Cu, Pt, Ni, and Ag. In their review, they systematically discussed MOF synthesis methodologies and some recent reports related to M NPs/MOFs (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Pd, Au, Ru, Cu, Pt, Ni, or Ag) catalysts that exhibit excellent performance for various reactions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Nanotechnology emerged as a new field in the 1980s and has since been a subject of extensive research interest. Self-assembly is the autonomous organization of components into patterns or structures without human intervention. In the MOF synthesis process, the molecules connect with each other through noncovalent bonds into a structurally stable molecular aggregate. Whitesides and Grzybowski  have speculated that such self-assembly will be an essential part of nanotechnology. The application of nanotechnology to the synthesis of MOFs enables the preparation of nanocrystalline materials with superior properties. Liu and Tang  have synthesized multifunctional nanoparticle@MOFs, that are core-shell nanostructures in which nanoparticles serve as the core and MOFs as the shell. Dhakshinamoorthy and Garcia's review  on catalysis by metal nanoparticles embedded in MOFs was organized according to the embedded metal and included Pd, Au, Ru, Cu, Pt, Ni, and Ag. In their review, they systematically discussed MOF synthesis methodologies and some recent reports related to M NPs/MOFs (M=Pd, Au, Ru, Cu, Pt, Ni, or Ag) catalysts that exhibit excellent performance for various reactions.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">In this paper, we describe our isolation of four new two-dimensional (2D) framework structures: Zn(3-bpdh)(HIA) (1Zn), Co(3-bpdh)(HIA) (2Co), Mn(3-bpdh)(HIA) (3Mn), and Zn(3-bpdh)(CHDC) (4Zn) (3-bpdh<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-3,4-diaza-2,4-hexadiene, HIA<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-hydroxyisophthalic acid, CHDC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylc acid). We also successfully synthesized microcrystals of these four compounds and herein discuss the potential applications of these microparticles as the support for several photocatalysts.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this paper, we describe our isolation of four new two-dimensional (2D) framework structures: Zn(3-bpdh)(HIA) (1Zn), Co(3-bpdh)(HIA) (2Co), Mn(3-bpdh)(HIA) (3Mn), and Zn(3-bpdh)(CHDC) (4Zn) (3-bpdh=2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-3,4-diaza-2,4-hexadiene, HIA=5-hydroxyisophthalic acid, CHDC=1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylc acid). We also successfully synthesized microcrystals of these four compounds and herein discuss the potential applications of these microparticles as the support for several photocatalysts.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The 1Zn crystals were synthesized in a test tube using the slow diffusion method. A mixture of HIA (54.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), NaOH (24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (89.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and distillated water (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was stirred to obtain a Zn–HIA aqueous solution, which was subsequently transferred to a test tube. Then, a 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL MeOH solution containing 3-bpdh (71.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol dissolved in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL MeOH) was carefully layered on top of the Zn–HIA aqueous solution (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) through a 1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL buffer solution consisting of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and MeOH in a volume ratio of 1:1 in the test tube. After one week, pale-yellow block crystals of [Zn(C<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>)]<ce:inf loc="post">∝</ce:inf> (1Zn) () suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis were obtained in the middle of the test tube. The synthesis procedures for the crystals of 2Co, 3Mn, and 4Zn were the same as that for 1Zn, except that Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (87.31<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and MnCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (59.37<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) were used instead of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (89.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) to prepare 2Co and 3Mn, respectively, and CHDC (50.46<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was added instead of the HIA (54.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) to prepare 4Zn.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The 1Zn crystals were synthesized in a test tube using the slow diffusion method. A mixture of HIA (54.6mg, 0.3mmol), NaOH (24mg, 0.6mmol), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (89.2mg, 0.3mmol), and distillated water (10mL) was stirred to obtain a Zn-HIA aqueous solution, which was subsequently transferred to a test tube. Then, a 4mL MeOH solution containing 3-bpdh (71.4mg, 0.3mmol dissolved in 10mL MeOH) was carefully layered on top of the Zn-HIA aqueous solution (4mL) through a 1.5mL buffer solution consisting of H2O and MeOH in a volume ratio of 1:1 in the test tube. After one week, pale-yellow block crystals of [Zn(C22H18N4O5)]∝ (1Zn) () suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis were obtained in the middle of the test tube. The synthesis procedures for the crystals of 2Co, 3Mn, and 4Zn were the same as that for 1Zn, except that Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (87.31mg, 0.3mmol) and MnCl2⋅4H2O (59.37mg, 0.3mmol) were used instead of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (89.2mg, 0.3mmol) to prepare 2Co and 3Mn, respectively, and CHDC (50.46mg, 0.3mmol) was added instead of the HIA (54.6mg, 0.3mmol) to prepare 4Zn.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Micro/nanocrystalline samples of 1Zn, 2Co, 3Mn, and 4Zn were synthesized under different conditions. The N-ligand 3-bpdh (71.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was added to an alcohol (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) solution in a 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL round-bottom flask to obtain a clear homogeneous solution. The Zn–HIA solution was then continuously injected into the magnetically stirred aforementioned N-ligand alcohol (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) solution at room temperature using an injection pump. The yellow micro/nanocrystals were collected for characterization. The synthesis procedures for the micro/nanocrystals of 2Co, 3Mn, and 4Zn were the same as that for 1Zn. The loaded catalyst TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@ZnMOF was synthesized as follows: a certain amount of 1Zn microcrystals was dispersed evenly in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL anhydrous ethanol; tetrabutyl titanate was then added to this mixture while stirring. After approximately 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min, 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL deionized water was added dropwise. The suspension was subsequently placed into an autoclave at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The loaded crystals were collected by vacuum filtration after the suspension had cooled.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Micro/nanocrystalline samples of 1Zn, 2Co, 3Mn, and 4Zn were synthesized under different conditions. The N-ligand 3-bpdh (71.4mg, 0.3mmol) was added to an alcohol (10mL) solution in a 50mL round-bottom flask to obtain a clear homogeneous solution. The Zn-HIA solution was then continuously injected into the magnetically stirred aforementioned N-ligand alcohol (10mL) solution at room temperature using an injection pump. The yellow micro/nanocrystals were collected for characterization. The synthesis procedures for the micro/nanocrystals of 2Co, 3Mn, and 4Zn were the same as that for 1Zn. The loaded catalyst TiO2@ZnMOF was synthesized as follows: a certain amount of 1Zn microcrystals was dispersed evenly in 10mL anhydrous ethanol; tetrabutyl titanate was then added to this mixture while stirring. After approximately 10min, 10mL deionized water was added dropwise. The suspension was subsequently placed into an autoclave at 100°C for 24h. The loaded crystals were collected by vacuum filtration after the suspension had cooled.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>, 1Zn crystallizes in triclinic space group <ce:italic>P-1</ce:italic> and exhibits a layered structure. Only one crystallographically independent Zn(II) is located in the six-member coordination environment. Four oxygen donors provided by carboxyl groups of HIA coordinate with the zinc ions in equatorial positions and two nitrogen atoms from 3-bpdh link to the zinc atom in axial positions. In 1Zn, the Zn–O bond lengths range from 1.984 to 2.008<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the Zn–N bond lengths are 2.190 and 2.197<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The octahedron around the Zn(II) ion is highly distorted: the N1–Zn1–N4 angle is 177.28° while the O–Zn–O angles vary from 96.29° to 137.63°. Crystallographic data of this complex are listed in Table S1. The carboxyl groups of each HIA coordinate with the zinc ions in bridging- and chelating-mode fashions. The Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> ions are chelated by one HIA and bridged by the other HIAs to produce double chains. The 3-bpdhs link to the Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> ions of the double chains to construct a 2D double-layer network in the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> plane. Interestingly, 2Co and 1Zn are isomorphous. For 2Co, the Co–O bond lengths range from 1.987 to 2.084<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, the Co–N lengths are 2.166 and 2.176<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, the N1–Co1–N4 angle is 177.07°, and the O–Co–O angles vary from 93.28° to 147.70°. The structure of 3Mn is very similar to that of 1Zn; it is also six-coordinated and located in the center of a deformed octahedron, where the nitrogen atoms on the pyridine ring of the ligand are coordinated with the ion and four oxygens from two carboxylic group of HIA are chelated with the metal ion. The Mn–O bond lengths range from 2.081(2) to 2.432(2) Å, the Mn–N lengths are 2.286 and 2.294<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, the N1–Mn1–N4 angle is 174.96°, and the O–Mn–O angles vary from 92.01° to 146.84°. 4Zn is constructed by two Zn(II) ions, two 1,4-CHDC ligands, and one 3-bpdh ligand. Each Zn(II) ion is coordinated in its equatorial positions by four oxygen atoms from 1,4-CHDC ligands and in its axial positions by two nitrogen atoms provided by 3-bpdh. The carboxyl groups of 1,4-CHDC link Zn(II) ions in a bridging manner to form double strands. The 3-bpdh ligand coordinates to one Zn(II) ion as a bridging ligand from layer structures. The Zn–O bond lengths range from 2.0304 to 2.0437<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, the Zn–Zn bond length is 2.8648<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Zn–N bond length is 2.046<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The O–Zn–O and O–Zn–N angles vary from 88.22 to 161.40° and from 95.34 to 103.22°, respectively, and the N–Zn–Zn angle is 170.42°. Zn···Zn metal interactions should occur in the complex because of the short distance among the Zn(II) ions. The MOFs self-assembly should be achieved by metal-ion potential and building-blocks. The outer electronic structures of ions, including those of Mn<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup>, Co<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup>, and Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup>, play an important role in the coordination structure for molecular design because they are responsible for the spatial direction of the coordination bonds. In our work, the metal ions Zn(II), Co(II), and Mn(II) bonded with HIA and 3-bpdh to form very similar space structures; these similarities resulted in complexes 1Zn and 2Co being isomorphous and in 3Mn exhibiting obvious differences in the space structure (e.g., bond lengths and angles) compared to that of 1Zn. All the building blocks are identical except for the metal ions, implying that their self-assembly could originate from center metal-ion potential, where the center metal-ion potential is ε<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ϕ/γ; ε, ϕ, and γ are metal-ion potential, metal-ion charge, and metal-ion radius, respectively). The metal-ion d<ce:sup loc="post">

elements.clean_text: As shown in  , 1Zn crystallizes in triclinic space group P-1 and exhibits a layered structure. Only one crystallographically independent Zn(II) is located in the six-member coordination environment. Four oxygen donors provided by carboxyl groups of HIA coordinate with the zinc ions in equatorial positions and two nitrogen atoms from 3-bpdh link to the zinc atom in axial positions. In 1Zn, the Zn-O bond lengths range from 1.984 to 2.008Å and the Zn-N bond lengths are 2.190 and 2.197Å. The octahedron around the Zn(II) ion is highly distorted: the N1-Zn1-N4 angle is 177.28° while the O-Zn-O angles vary from 96.29° to 137.63°. Crystallographic data of this complex are listed in Table S1. The carboxyl groups of each HIA coordinate with the zinc ions in bridging- and chelating-mode fashions. The Zn2+ ions are chelated by one HIA and bridged by the other HIAs to produce double chains. The 3-bpdhs link to the Zn2+ ions of the double chains to construct a 2D double-layer network in the b-c plane. Interestingly, 2Co and 1Zn are isomorphous. For 2Co, the Co-O bond lengths range from 1.987 to 2.084Å, the Co-N lengths are 2.166 and 2.176Å, the N1-Co1-N4 angle is 177.07°, and the O-Co-O angles vary from 93.28° to 147.70°. The structure of 3Mn is very similar to that of 1Zn; it is also six-coordinated and located in the center of a deformed octahedron, where the nitrogen atoms on the pyridine ring of the ligand are coordinated with the ion and four oxygens from two carboxylic group of HIA are chelated with the metal ion. The Mn-O bond lengths range from 2.081(2) to 2.432(2) Å, the Mn-N lengths are 2.286 and 2.294Å, the N1-Mn1-N4 angle is 174.96°, and the O-Mn-O angles vary from 92.01° to 146.84°. 4Zn is constructed by two Zn(II) ions, two 1,4-CHDC ligands, and one 3-bpdh ligand. Each Zn(II) ion is coordinated in its equatorial positions by four oxygen atoms from 1,4-CHDC ligands and in its axial positions by two nitrogen atoms provided by 3-bpdh. The carboxyl groups of 1,4-CHDC link Zn(II) ions in a bridging manner to form double strands. The 3-bpdh ligand coordinates to one Zn(II) ion as a bridging ligand from layer structures. The Zn-O bond lengths range from 2.0304 to 2.0437Å, the Zn-Zn bond length is 2.8648Å, and the Zn-N bond length is 2.046Å. The O-Zn-O and O-Zn-N angles vary from 88.22 to 161.40° and from 95.34 to 103.22°, respectively, and the N-Zn-Zn angle is 170.42°. Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn metal interactions should occur in the complex because of the short distance among the Zn(II) ions. The MOFs self-assembly should be achieved by metal-ion potential and building-blocks. The outer electronic structures of ions, including those of Mn2+, Co2+, and Zn2+, play an important role in the coordination structure for molecular design because they are responsible for the spatial direction of the coordination bonds. In our work, the metal ions Zn(II), Co(II), and Mn(II) bonded with HIA and 3-bpdh to form very similar space structures; these similarities resulted in complexes 1Zn and 2Co being isomorphous and in 3Mn exhibiting obvious differences in the space structure (e.g., bond lengths and angles) compared to that of 1Zn. All the building blocks are identical except for the metal ions, implying that their self-assembly could originate from center metal-ion potential, where the center metal-ion potential is ε=ϕ/γ; ε, ϕ, and γ are metal-ion potential, metal-ion charge, and metal-ion radius, respectively). The metal-ion d n  electron configurations are d5 for Mn2+, d7 for Co2+, and d10 for Zn2+, whose center metal-ion charges (ϕ) are all identical, and their metal-ion radii are similar with respect to coordinated bond lengths and corresponding atom radii (coordinated bond lengths in IS: r Zn(1)-O =1.98~2.01Å, r Zn(1)-N =2.19~2.20Å for 1Zn; r Co(1)-O =1.99~2.08Å, r Co(1)-N =2.17~2.18Å for 2Co; r Mn(1)-O =2.08~2.43Å, r Mn(1)-N =2.28~2.29Å for 3Mn, atom radii: r Zn =0.74Å, r Co =0.745Å, and r Mn =0.83Å). This results in the center metal-ion potential to be εZn =ϕ/γZn =εCo =ϕ/γCo ~εMn =ϕ/γMn. The complex 4Zn differs substantially from complexes 1Zn, 2Co, and 3Mn because of the differences between the 1,4-CHDC and HIA ligands, demonstrating the importance of the building blocks in molecular design and construction. (See  .)

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) results (Fig. S13) indicated that Ti cations were present on the surface of 1ZnMOFs. The EDS quantitative elemental analysis results for the compound catalysts (the mass ratio of 1ZnMOF to TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> is 2:3) are listed in Table S10; these results provide direct evidence that TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was coated onto the surface of micro-1ZnMOF. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>, the powder XRD patterns of 1Zn and 2Co are in accordance with the simulated XRD pattern based on the single-crystal structure data, which illustrates that these two MOFs possess the same crystal structure and that the small crystals are very pure. In addition, the 3Mn and 4Zn are also very pure. The powder XRD patterns in  also provide further evidence that 1ZnMOF was coated with TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. After being autoclaved at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, the 1ZnMOF retained its structure; the only change was that when the mass ratio between 1ZnMOF and TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> increased, the peaks of anatase TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at 25° and 37°  became more obvious.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) results (Fig. S13) indicated that Ti cations were present on the surface of 1ZnMOFs. The EDS quantitative elemental analysis results for the compound catalysts (the mass ratio of 1ZnMOF to TiO2 is 2:3) are listed in Table S10; these results provide direct evidence that TiO2 was coated onto the surface of micro-1ZnMOF. As shown in  , the powder XRD patterns of 1Zn and 2Co are in accordance with the simulated XRD pattern based on the single-crystal structure data, which illustrates that these two MOFs possess the same crystal structure and that the small crystals are very pure. In addition, the 3Mn and 4Zn are also very pure. The powder XRD patterns in  also provide further evidence that 1ZnMOF was coated with TiO2. After being autoclaved at 100°C for 24h, the 1ZnMOF retained its structure; the only change was that when the mass ratio between 1ZnMOF and TiO2 increased, the peaks of anatase TiO2 at 25° and 37°  became more obvious.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0055" view="all">In this work, one of the simplest ways to obtain uniform particles was to fabricate monodispersed colloidal microcrystals and nanocrystals, also known as colloidal crystals. The colloidal MOF micro/nanocrystals of desired size were controllably fabricated by variation of the reaction time in a methanol–H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O solvent system; this method is known as time-resolved progress . An aqueous-phase solution of M<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup>–carboxylate was continuously injected using a burette into an oil-phase mixture solution containing 3-bpdh under vigorous stirring at room temperature. Eventually, a very intense suspension developed. As the two phases slowly diffused into each other, the MOF species self-assembled into monodispersed particles. The products were precipitated and collected.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this work, one of the simplest ways to obtain uniform particles was to fabricate monodispersed colloidal microcrystals and nanocrystals, also known as colloidal crystals. The colloidal MOF micro/nanocrystals of desired size were controllably fabricated by variation of the reaction time in a methanol-H2O solvent system; this method is known as time-resolved progress . An aqueous-phase solution of M2+-carboxylate was continuously injected using a burette into an oil-phase mixture solution containing 3-bpdh under vigorous stirring at room temperature. Eventually, a very intense suspension developed. As the two phases slowly diffused into each other, the MOF species self-assembled into monodispersed particles. The products were precipitated and collected.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>, when the reaction time was varied from 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min to 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images revealed that the resulting materials exhibited different morphologies and sizes of micro/nanocrystals, depending on the reaction time in the methanol–H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O system. The 1Zn exhibited a monodisperse well-shaped microspherical morphology; the average size of the microspheres was approximately 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μm and they were tightly assembled by small patches. The micro/nanocrystals of 2Co, 3Mn, and 4Zn were clusters assembled by small grain-like crystals, microspheres assembled by small sheet-shaped crystals, and microspheres assembled by small rule-like crystals, respectively. Further studies demonstrated that the 2Co, 3Mn, and 4Zn microcrystals and nanocrystals were readily formed by quick reaction and exhibited well-defined morphologies. With longer reaction times, no changes in morphology were observed for 1Zn and 2Co; however, when the reaction time was increased to 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, the microspheres of 3Mn and 4Zn tended to be broken into smaller pieces as a consequence of their molecular structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As shown in  , when the reaction time was varied from 10min to 3h, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images revealed that the resulting materials exhibited different morphologies and sizes of micro/nanocrystals, depending on the reaction time in the methanol-H2O system. The 1Zn exhibited a monodisperse well-shaped microspherical morphology; the average size of the microspheres was approximately 5μm and they were tightly assembled by small patches. The micro/nanocrystals of 2Co, 3Mn, and 4Zn were clusters assembled by small grain-like crystals, microspheres assembled by small sheet-shaped crystals, and microspheres assembled by small rule-like crystals, respectively. Further studies demonstrated that the 2Co, 3Mn, and 4Zn microcrystals and nanocrystals were readily formed by quick reaction and exhibited well-defined morphologies. With longer reaction times, no changes in morphology were observed for 1Zn and 2Co; however, when the reaction time was increased to 3h, the microspheres of 3Mn and 4Zn tended to be broken into smaller pieces as a consequence of their molecular structures.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Given their size and stability, 1Zn microcrystals were selected as the support material for different photocatalysts in this work. BiWO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, Ag<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, and TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> are known to be highly efficient catalysts ; we attempted to coat these materials onto 1Zn micro-MOFs. The 1Zn micro-MOFs were surrounded with curly BiWO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> particles (Fig. S11), whereas cubic Ag<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> grains clustered together. The 1Zn micro-MOFs could be coated evenly to form a core–shell-type catalyst because of the smaller size of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. We subsequently focused our work on studies in which the ratio between 1Zn micro-MOFs and TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was varied. The amount of 1Zn micro-MOFs was 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg in each experiment, and the amount of tetrabutyl titanate, which we used to prepare TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> by hydrolysis, was varied . To determine the TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> photocatalytic performance, TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> crystallization at high temperature is required. TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@1ZnMOF was heated in an autoclave at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h . The final TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@1ZnMOF mass ratios were 1:6, 1:3, 2:3, and 4:3. The SEM images of the TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@1ZnMOF in Fig. S12 indicate that with increasing TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/1ZnMOF mass ratio, progressively larger amounts of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> coated the surface of 1ZnMOF, resulting in an increasingly thick shell. When the mass ratio reached 4:3, the shape of the 1ZnMOF was difficult to discern because of the large amount of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> coating the surface of the MOF.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Given their size and stability, 1Zn microcrystals were selected as the support material for different photocatalysts in this work. BiWO4, Ag3PO4, and TiO2 are known to be highly efficient catalysts ; we attempted to coat these materials onto 1Zn micro-MOFs. The 1Zn micro-MOFs were surrounded with curly BiWO4 particles (Fig. S11), whereas cubic Ag3PO4 grains clustered together. The 1Zn micro-MOFs could be coated evenly to form a core-shell-type catalyst because of the smaller size of TiO2. We subsequently focused our work on studies in which the ratio between 1Zn micro-MOFs and TiO2 was varied. The amount of 1Zn micro-MOFs was 80mg in each experiment, and the amount of tetrabutyl titanate, which we used to prepare TiO2 by hydrolysis, was varied . To determine the TiO2 photocatalytic performance, TiO2 crystallization at high temperature is required. TiO2@1ZnMOF was heated in an autoclave at 100°C for 24h . The final TiO2@1ZnMOF mass ratios were 1:6, 1:3, 2:3, and 4:3. The SEM images of the TiO2@1ZnMOF in Fig. S12 indicate that with increasing TiO2/1ZnMOF mass ratio, progressively larger amounts of TiO2 coated the surface of 1ZnMOF, resulting in an increasingly thick shell. When the mass ratio reached 4:3, the shape of the 1ZnMOF was difficult to discern because of the large amount of TiO2 coating the surface of the MOF.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">In our investigation of the photocatalytic properties (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>), the amount of 1ZnMOF, P25, TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and loaded catalyst was 60<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg. The concentration of methylene blue was 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm. Apparently, the 1ZnMOF exhibits no apparently photocatalytic activity toward methylene blue. The degradation rate of the TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> prepared in our lab was only 17%. When the TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/1ZnMOF mass ratio of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@1ZnMOF was 1:6, the degradation rate was 14%, which was lower than that of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> alone because of the lower content of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. While the content of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> in the loaded catalysts was 25%, the degradation rate reached 43%. Remarkably, we achieved a degradation rate of 64% when the TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/1ZnMOF mass ratio was 2:3. Compared with the P25, whose degradation rate was 31%, the loaded and compound catalysts exhibit better photocatalytic efficiency. Based on a related paper , the mechanism for catalytic degradation of methylene blue is proposed as follows: methylene blue molecules adsorb on the surface of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and contact the TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> nanoparticles directly, which induces surface lattice distortion in a region of several atom layers because of lattice matching in order to provide a key intermediate state during photocatalyzing; then, the distorted lattice atoms absorb photons and tend to recover, which induces a kind of surface lattice driving force by light, and the absorption of photons can increase the lattice energy of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> causing the distorted lattice atoms to recover. This surface latticed driving force can cut the molecule bond and result in the degradation of methylene blue; the distorted lattice is recovered along with the degradation of methylene blue molecules. Thus, in the photocatalytic process, TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> can be visualized as a lattice engine based on the variation distortion …recovery…distortion…recovery...of the lattice , which leads to the degradation of organic molecules. In our work, the 1ZnMOF is soaked in the solution of tetrabutyl titanate solved in anhydrous ethanol, a thin layer of tetrabutyl titanate was formed on the surface of the 1ZnMOF microspheres. After the deionized water was dropped onto the soaked 1ZnMOF, the microspheres were loaded with and even coating of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> nanoparticles. The loaded catalysts exhibited improved photocatalytic efficiency compared to P25 and the TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> prepared in our lab. One possible mechanism of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@1ZnMOF enhancing the catalytic degradation of methylene blue is TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> coating 1ZnMOF to disperse small TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> particles and increase its surface area, which is conducive to the photocatalytic reaction (TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@1ZnMOF in Fig. S14) compared with pure TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> particles that can easily form block product. In contrast, MOFs usually provide a rigid scaffold and possess chromophoric sensitizers serving as a “lantern,” which results in the transformation of a large number of photons per unit volume from MOFs to TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, thus increasing the quantity of absorbed photons and enhancing the photocatalytic effect.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In our investigation of the photocatalytic properties ( ), the amount of 1ZnMOF, P25, TiO2, and loaded catalyst was 60mg. The concentration of methylene blue was 12ppm. Apparently, the 1ZnMOF exhibits no apparently photocatalytic activity toward methylene blue. The degradation rate of the TiO2 prepared in our lab was only 17%. When the TiO2/1ZnMOF mass ratio of TiO2@1ZnMOF was 1:6, the degradation rate was 14%, which was lower than that of TiO2 alone because of the lower content of TiO2. While the content of TiO2 in the loaded catalysts was 25%, the degradation rate reached 43%. Remarkably, we achieved a degradation rate of 64% when the TiO2/1ZnMOF mass ratio was 2:3. Compared with the P25, whose degradation rate was 31%, the loaded and compound catalysts exhibit better photocatalytic efficiency. Based on a related paper , the mechanism for catalytic degradation of methylene blue is proposed as follows: methylene blue molecules adsorb on the surface of TiO2 and contact the TiO2 nanoparticles directly, which induces surface lattice distortion in a region of several atom layers because of lattice matching in order to provide a key intermediate state during photocatalyzing; then, the distorted lattice atoms absorb photons and tend to recover, which induces a kind of surface lattice driving force by light, and the absorption of photons can increase the lattice energy of TiO2 causing the distorted lattice atoms to recover. This surface latticed driving force can cut the molecule bond and result in the degradation of methylene blue; the distorted lattice is recovered along with the degradation of methylene blue molecules. Thus, in the photocatalytic process, TiO2 can be visualized as a lattice engine based on the variation distortion …recovery…distortion…recovery...of the lattice , which leads to the degradation of organic molecules. In our work, the 1ZnMOF is soaked in the solution of tetrabutyl titanate solved in anhydrous ethanol, a thin layer of tetrabutyl titanate was formed on the surface of the 1ZnMOF microspheres. After the deionized water was dropped onto the soaked 1ZnMOF, the microspheres were loaded with and even coating of TiO2 nanoparticles. The loaded catalysts exhibited improved photocatalytic efficiency compared to P25 and the TiO2 prepared in our lab. One possible mechanism of TiO2@1ZnMOF enhancing the catalytic degradation of methylene blue is TiO2 coating 1ZnMOF to disperse small TiO2 particles and increase its surface area, which is conducive to the photocatalytic reaction (TiO2@1ZnMOF in Fig. S14) compared with pure TiO2 particles that can easily form block product. In contrast, MOFs usually provide a rigid scaffold and possess chromophoric sensitizers serving as a "lantern," which results in the transformation of a large number of photons per unit volume from MOFs to TiO2, thus increasing the quantity of absorbed photons and enhancing the photocatalytic effect.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0075" view="all">In this study, we successfully synthesized four new 2D MOF materials—1Zn, 2Co, 3Mn, and 4Zn—and their microcrystals. We demonstrated that the microcrystals of 1Zn are a suitable support for loading with TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> catalyst, resulting in core–shell-structured TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@1ZnMOF with excellent conversion (64%) and selectivity in the photocatalytic degradation of MB. The high flexibility of this strategy and the effective catalytic properties of the resulting materials will certainly expand the study of functional materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this study, we successfully synthesized four new 2D MOF materials-1Zn, 2Co, 3Mn, and 4Zn-and their microcrystals. We demonstrated that the microcrystals of 1Zn are a suitable support for loading with TiO2 catalyst, resulting in core-shell-structured TiO2@1ZnMOF with excellent conversion (64%) and selectivity in the photocatalytic degradation of MB. The high flexibility of this strategy and the effective catalytic properties of the resulting materials will certainly expand the study of functional materials.

cln_elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The 1Zn crystals were synthesized in a test tube using the slow diffusion method. A mixture of HIA (54.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), NaOH (24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (89.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and distillated water (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was stirred to obtain a Zn–HIA aqueous solution, which was subsequently transferred to a test tube. Then, a 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL MeOH solution containing 3-bpdh (71.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol dissolved in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL MeOH) was carefully layered on top of the Zn–HIA aqueous solution (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) through a 1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL buffer solution consisting of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and MeOH in a volume ratio of 1:1 in the test tube. After one week, pale-yellow block crystals of [Zn(C<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>)]<ce:inf loc="post">∝</ce:inf> (1Zn) () suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis were obtained in the middle of the test tube. The synthesis procedures for the crystals of 2Co, 3Mn, and 4Zn were the same as that for 1Zn, except that Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (87.31<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and MnCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (59.37<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) were used instead of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (89.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) to prepare 2Co and 3Mn, respectively, and CHDC (50.46<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was added instead of the HIA (54.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) to prepare 4Zn.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Micro/nanocrystalline samples of 1Zn, 2Co, 3Mn, and 4Zn were synthesized under different conditions. The N-ligand 3-bpdh (71.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was added to an alcohol (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) solution in a 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL round-bottom flask to obtain a clear homogeneous solution. The Zn–HIA solution was then continuously injected into the magnetically stirred aforementioned N-ligand alcohol (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) solution at room temperature using an injection pump. The yellow micro/nanocrystals were collected for characterization. The synthesis procedures for the micro/nanocrystals of 2Co, 3Mn, and 4Zn were the same as that for 1Zn. The loaded catalyst TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@ZnMOF was synthesized as follows: a certain amount of 1Zn microcrystals was dispersed evenly in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL anhydrous ethanol; tetrabutyl titanate was then added to this mixture while stirring. After approximately 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min, 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL deionized water was added dropwise. The suspension was subsequently placed into an autoclave at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The loaded crystals were collected by vacuum filtration after the suspension had cooled.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Given their size and stability, 1Zn microcrystals were selected as the support material for different photocatalysts in this work. BiWO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, Ag<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, and TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> are known to be highly efficient catalysts ; we attempted to coat these materials onto 1Zn micro-MOFs. The 1Zn micro-MOFs were surrounded with curly BiWO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> particles (Fig. S11), whereas cubic Ag<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> grains clustered together. The 1Zn micro-MOFs could be coated evenly to form a core–shell-type catalyst because of the smaller size of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. We subsequently focused our work on studies in which the ratio between 1Zn micro-MOFs and TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was varied. The amount of 1Zn micro-MOFs was 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg in each experiment, and the amount of tetrabutyl titanate, which we used to prepare TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> by hydrolysis, was varied . To determine the TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> photocatalytic performance, TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> crystallization at high temperature is required. TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@1ZnMOF was heated in an autoclave at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h . The final TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@1ZnMOF mass ratios were 1:6, 1:3, 2:3, and 4:3. The SEM images of the TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@1ZnMOF in Fig. S12 indicate that with increasing TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/1ZnMOF mass ratio, progressively larger amounts of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> coated the surface of 1ZnMOF, resulting in an increasingly thick shell. When the mass ratio reached 4:3, the shape of the 1ZnMOF was difficult to discern because of the large amount of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> coating the surface of the MOF.</ce:para>

The 1Zn crystals were synthesized in a test tube using the slow diffusion method. A mixture of HIA (54.6mg, 0.3mmol), NaOH (24mg, 0.6mmol), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (89.2mg, 0.3mmol), and distillated water (10mL) was stirred to obtain a Zn-HIA aqueous solution, which was subsequently transferred to a test tube. Then, a 4mL MeOH solution containing 3-bpdh (71.4mg, 0.3mmol dissolved in 10mL MeOH) was carefully layered on top of the Zn-HIA aqueous solution (4mL) through a 1.5mL buffer solution consisting of H2O and MeOH in a volume ratio of 1:1 in the test tube. After one week, pale-yellow block crystals of [Zn(C22H18N4O5)]∝ (1Zn) () suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis were obtained in the middle of the test tube. The synthesis procedures for the crystals of 2Co, 3Mn, and 4Zn were the same as that for 1Zn, except that Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (87.31mg, 0.3mmol) and MnCl2⋅4H2O (59.37mg, 0.3mmol) were used instead of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (89.2mg, 0.3mmol) to prepare 2Co and 3Mn, respectively, and CHDC (50.46mg, 0.3mmol) was added instead of the HIA (54.6mg, 0.3mmol) to prepare 4Zn.

Micro/nanocrystalline samples of 1Zn, 2Co, 3Mn, and 4Zn were synthesized under different conditions. The N-ligand 3-bpdh (71.4mg, 0.3mmol) was added to an alcohol (10mL) solution in a 50mL round-bottom flask to obtain a clear homogeneous solution. The Zn-HIA solution was then continuously injected into the magnetically stirred aforementioned N-ligand alcohol (10mL) solution at room temperature using an injection pump. The yellow micro/nanocrystals were collected for characterization. The synthesis procedures for the micro/nanocrystals of 2Co, 3Mn, and 4Zn were the same as that for 1Zn. The loaded catalyst TiO2@ZnMOF was synthesized as follows: a certain amount of 1Zn microcrystals was dispersed evenly in 10mL anhydrous ethanol; tetrabutyl titanate was then added to this mixture while stirring. After approximately 10min, 10mL deionized water was added dropwise. The suspension was subsequently placed into an autoclave at 100°C for 24h. The loaded crystals were collected by vacuum filtration after the suspension had cooled.

Given their size and stability, 1Zn microcrystals were selected as the support material for different photocatalysts in this work. BiWO4, Ag3PO4, and TiO2 are known to be highly efficient catalysts ; we attempted to coat these materials onto 1Zn micro-MOFs. The 1Zn micro-MOFs were surrounded with curly BiWO4 particles (Fig. S11), whereas cubic Ag3PO4 grains clustered together. The 1Zn micro-MOFs could be coated evenly to form a core-shell-type catalyst because of the smaller size of TiO2. We subsequently focused our work on studies in which the ratio between 1Zn micro-MOFs and TiO2 was varied. The amount of 1Zn micro-MOFs was 80mg in each experiment, and the amount of tetrabutyl titanate, which we used to prepare TiO2 by hydrolysis, was varied . To determine the TiO2 photocatalytic performance, TiO2 crystallization at high temperature is required. TiO2@1ZnMOF was heated in an autoclave at 100°C for 24h . The final TiO2@1ZnMOF mass ratios were 1:6, 1:3, 2:3, and 4:3. The SEM images of the TiO2@1ZnMOF in Fig. S12 indicate that with increasing TiO2/1ZnMOF mass ratio, progressively larger amounts of TiO2 coated the surface of 1ZnMOF, resulting in an increasingly thick shell. When the mass ratio reached 4:3, the shape of the 1ZnMOF was difficult to discern because of the large amount of TiO2 coating the surface of the MOF.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>, 1Zn crystallizes in triclinic space group <ce:italic>P-1</ce:italic> and exhibits a layered structure. Only one crystallographically independent Zn(II) is located in the six-member coordination environment. Four oxygen donors provided by carboxyl groups of HIA coordinate with the zinc ions in equatorial positions and two nitrogen atoms from 3-bpdh link to the zinc atom in axial positions. In 1Zn, the Zn–O bond lengths range from 1.984 to 2.008<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the Zn–N bond lengths are 2.190 and 2.197<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The octahedron around the Zn(II) ion is highly distorted: the N1–Zn1–N4 angle is 177.28° while the O–Zn–O angles vary from 96.29° to 137.63°. Crystallographic data of this complex are listed in Table S1. The carboxyl groups of each HIA coordinate with the zinc ions in bridging- and chelating-mode fashions. The Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> ions are chelated by one HIA and bridged by the other HIAs to produce double chains. The 3-bpdhs link to the Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> ions of the double chains to construct a 2D double-layer network in the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> plane. Interestingly, 2Co and 1Zn are isomorphous. For 2Co, the Co–O bond lengths range from 1.987 to 2.084<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, the Co–N lengths are 2.166 and 2.176<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, the N1–Co1–N4 angle is 177.07°, and the O–Co–O angles vary from 93.28° to 147.70°. The structure of 3Mn is very similar to that of 1Zn; it is also six-coordinated and located in the center of a deformed octahedron, where the nitrogen atoms on the pyridine ring of the ligand are coordinated with the ion and four oxygens from two carboxylic group of HIA are chelated with the metal ion. The Mn–O bond lengths range from 2.081(2) to 2.432(2) Å, the Mn–N lengths are 2.286 and 2.294<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, the N1–Mn1–N4 angle is 174.96°, and the O–Mn–O angles vary from 92.01° to 146.84°. 4Zn is constructed by two Zn(II) ions, two 1,4-CHDC ligands, and one 3-bpdh ligand. Each Zn(II) ion is coordinated in its equatorial positions by four oxygen atoms from 1,4-CHDC ligands and in its axial positions by two nitrogen atoms provided by 3-bpdh. The carboxyl groups of 1,4-CHDC link Zn(II) ions in a bridging manner to form double strands. The 3-bpdh ligand coordinates to one Zn(II) ion as a bridging ligand from layer structures. The Zn–O bond lengths range from 2.0304 to 2.0437<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, the Zn–Zn bond length is 2.8648<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Zn–N bond length is 2.046<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The O–Zn–O and O–Zn–N angles vary from 88.22 to 161.40° and from 95.34 to 103.22°, respectively, and the N–Zn–Zn angle is 170.42°. Zn···Zn metal interactions should occur in the complex because of the short distance among the Zn(II) ions. The MOFs self-assembly should be achieved by metal-ion potential and building-blocks. The outer electronic structures of ions, including those of Mn<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup>, Co<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup>, and Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup>, play an important role in the coordination structure for molecular design because they are responsible for the spatial direction of the coordination bonds. In our work, the metal ions Zn(II), Co(II), and Mn(II) bonded with HIA and 3-bpdh to form very similar space structures; these similarities resulted in complexes 1Zn and 2Co being isomorphous and in 3Mn exhibiting obvious differences in the space structure (e.g., bond lengths and angles) compared to that of 1Zn. All the building blocks are identical except for the metal ions, implying that their self-assembly could originate from center metal-ion potential, where the center metal-ion potential is ε<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ϕ/γ; ε, ϕ, and γ are metal-ion potential, metal-ion charge, and metal-ion radius, respectively). The metal-ion d<ce:sup loc="post">

The concentration of methylene blue was 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm. Apparently, the 1ZnMOF exhibits no apparently photocatalytic activity toward methylene blue. The degradation rate of the TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> prepared in our lab was only 17%. When the TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/1ZnMOF mass ratio of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@1ZnMOF was 1:6, the degradation rate was 14%, which was lower than that of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> alone because of the lower content of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. While the content of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> in the loaded catalysts was 25%, the degradation rate reached 43%. Remarkably, we achieved a degradation rate of 64% when the TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/1ZnMOF mass ratio was 2:3. Compared with the P25, whose degradation rate was 31%, the loaded and compound catalysts exhibit better photocatalytic efficiency. Based on a related paper , the mechanism for catalytic degradation of methylene blue is proposed as follows: methylene blue molecules adsorb on the surface of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and contact the TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> nanoparticles directly, which induces surface lattice distortion in a region of several atom layers because of lattice matching in order to provide a key intermediate state during photocatalyzing; then, the distorted lattice atoms absorb photons and tend to recover, which induces a kind of surface lattice driving force by light, and the absorption of photons can increase the lattice energy of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> causing the distorted lattice atoms to recover. This surface latticed driving force can cut the molecule bond and result in the degradation of methylene blue; the distorted lattice is recovered along with the degradation of methylene blue molecules. Thus, in the photocatalytic process, TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> can be visualized as a lattice engine based on the variation distortion …recovery…distortion…recovery...of the lattice , which leads to the degradation of organic molecules. In our work, the 1ZnMOF is soaked in the solution of tetrabutyl titanate solved in anhydrous ethanol, a thin layer of tetrabutyl titanate was formed on the surface of the 1ZnMOF microspheres. After the deionized water was dropped onto the soaked 1ZnMOF, the microspheres were loaded with and even coating of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> nanoparticles. The loaded catalysts exhibited improved photocatalytic efficiency compared to P25 and the TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> prepared in our lab. One possible mechanism of TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@1ZnMOF enhancing the catalytic degradation of methylene blue is TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> coating 1ZnMOF to disperse small TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> particles and increase its surface area, which is conducive to the photocatalytic reaction (TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@1ZnMOF in Fig. S14) compared with pure TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> particles that can easily form block product. In contrast, MOFs usually provide a rigid scaffold and possess chromophoric sensitizers serving as a “lantern,” which results in the transformation of a large number of photons per unit volume from MOFs to TiO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, thus increasing the quantity of absorbed photons and enhancing the photocatalytic effect.</ce:para>

As shown in  , 1Zn crystallizes in triclinic space group P-1 and exhibits a layered structure. Only one crystallographically independent Zn(II) is located in the six-member coordination environment. Four oxygen donors provided by carboxyl groups of HIA coordinate with the zinc ions in equatorial positions and two nitrogen atoms from 3-bpdh link to the zinc atom in axial positions. In 1Zn, the Zn-O bond lengths range from 1.984 to 2.008Å and the Zn-N bond lengths are 2.190 and 2.197Å. The octahedron around the Zn(II) ion is highly distorted: the N1-Zn1-N4 angle is 177.28° while the O-Zn-O angles vary from 96.29° to 137.63°. Crystallographic data of this complex are listed in Table S1. The carboxyl groups of each HIA coordinate with the zinc ions in bridging- and chelating-mode fashions. The Zn2+ ions are chelated by one HIA and bridged by the other HIAs to produce double chains. The 3-bpdhs link to the Zn2+ ions of the double chains to construct a 2D double-layer network in the b-c plane. Interestingly, 2Co and 1Zn are isomorphous. For 2Co, the Co-O bond lengths range from 1.987 to 2.084Å, the Co-N lengths are 2.166 and 2.176Å, the N1-Co1-N4 angle is 177.07°, and the O-Co-O angles vary from 93.28° to 147.70°. The structure of 3Mn is very similar to that of 1Zn; it is also six-coordinated and located in the center of a deformed octahedron, where the nitrogen atoms on the pyridine ring of the ligand are coordinated with the ion and four oxygens from two carboxylic group of HIA are chelated with the metal ion. The Mn-O bond lengths range from 2.081(2) to 2.432(2) Å, the Mn-N lengths are 2.286 and 2.294Å, the N1-Mn1-N4 angle is 174.96°, and the O-Mn-O angles vary from 92.01° to 146.84°. 4Zn is constructed by two Zn(II) ions, two 1,4-CHDC ligands, and one 3-bpdh ligand. Each Zn(II) ion is coordinated in its equatorial positions by four oxygen atoms from 1,4-CHDC ligands and in its axial positions by two nitrogen atoms provided by 3-bpdh. The carboxyl groups of 1,4-CHDC link Zn(II) ions in a bridging manner to form double strands. The 3-bpdh ligand coordinates to one Zn(II) ion as a bridging ligand from layer structures. The Zn-O bond lengths range from 2.0304 to 2.0437Å, the Zn-Zn bond length is 2.8648Å, and the Zn-N bond length is 2.046Å. The O-Zn-O and O-Zn-N angles vary from 88.22 to 161.40° and from 95.34 to 103.22°, respectively, and the N-Zn-Zn angle is 170.42°. Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn metal interactions should occur in the complex because of the short distance among the Zn(II) ions. The MOFs self-assembly should be achieved by metal-ion potential and building-blocks. The outer electronic structures of ions, including those of Mn2+, Co2+, and Zn2+, play an important role in the coordination structure for molecular design because they are responsible for the spatial direction of the coordination bonds. In our work, the metal ions Zn(II), Co(II), and Mn(II) bonded with HIA and 3-bpdh to form very similar space structures; these similarities resulted in complexes 1Zn and 2Co being isomorphous and in 3Mn exhibiting obvious differences in the space structure (e.g., bond lengths and angles) compared to that of 1Zn. All the building blocks are identical except for the metal ions, implying that their self-assembly could originate from center metal-ion potential, where the center metal-ion potential is ε=ϕ/γ; ε, ϕ, and γ are metal-ion potential, metal-ion charge, and metal-ion radius, respectively). The metal-ion d n  electron configurations are d5 for Mn2+, d7 for Co2+, and d10 for Zn2+, whose center metal-ion charges (ϕ) are all identical, and their metal-ion radii are similar with respect to coordinated bond lengths and corresponding atom radii (coordinated bond lengths in IS: r Zn(1)-O =1.98~2.01Å, r Zn(1)-N =2.19~2.20Å for 1Zn; r Co(1)-O =1.99~2.08Å, r Co(1)-N =2.17~2.18Å for 2Co; r Mn(1)-O =2.08~2.43Å, r Mn(1)-N =2.28~2.29Å for 3Mn, atom radii: r Zn =0.74Å, r Co =0.745Å, and r Mn =0.83Å). This results in the center metal-ion potential to be εZn =ϕ/γZn =εCo =ϕ/γCo ~εMn =ϕ/γMn. The complex 4Zn differs substantially from complexes 1Zn, 2Co, and 3Mn because of the differences between the 1,4-CHDC and HIA ligands, demonstrating the importance of the building blocks in molecular design and construction. (See  .)

In our investigation of the photocatalytic properties ( ), the amount of 1ZnMOF, P25, TiO2, and loaded catalyst was 60mg. The concentration of methylene blue was 12ppm. Apparently, the 1ZnMOF exhibits no apparently photocatalytic activity toward methylene blue. The degradation rate of the TiO2 prepared in our lab was only 17%. When the TiO2/1ZnMOF mass ratio of TiO2@1ZnMOF was 1:6, the degradation rate was 14%, which was lower than that of TiO2 alone because of the lower content of TiO2. While the content of TiO2 in the loaded catalysts was 25%, the degradation rate reached 43%. Remarkably, we achieved a degradation rate of 64% when the TiO2/1ZnMOF mass ratio was 2:3. Compared with the P25, whose degradation rate was 31%, the loaded and compound catalysts exhibit better photocatalytic efficiency. Based on a related paper , the mechanism for catalytic degradation of methylene blue is proposed as follows: methylene blue molecules adsorb on the surface of TiO2 and contact the TiO2 nanoparticles directly, which induces surface lattice distortion in a region of several atom layers because of lattice matching in order to provide a key intermediate state during photocatalyzing; then, the distorted lattice atoms absorb photons and tend to recover, which induces a kind of surface lattice driving force by light, and the absorption of photons can increase the lattice energy of TiO2 causing the distorted lattice atoms to recover. This surface latticed driving force can cut the molecule bond and result in the degradation of methylene blue; the distorted lattice is recovered along with the degradation of methylene blue molecules. Thus, in the photocatalytic process, TiO2 can be visualized as a lattice engine based on the variation distortion …recovery…distortion…recovery...of the lattice , which leads to the degradation of organic molecules. In our work, the 1ZnMOF is soaked in the solution of tetrabutyl titanate solved in anhydrous ethanol, a thin layer of tetrabutyl titanate was formed on the surface of the 1ZnMOF microspheres. After the deionized water was dropped onto the soaked 1ZnMOF, the microspheres were loaded with and even coating of TiO2 nanoparticles. The loaded catalysts exhibited improved photocatalytic efficiency compared to P25 and the TiO2 prepared in our lab. One possible mechanism of TiO2@1ZnMOF enhancing the catalytic degradation of methylene blue is TiO2 coating 1ZnMOF to disperse small TiO2 particles and increase its surface area, which is conducive to the photocatalytic reaction (TiO2@1ZnMOF in Fig. S14) compared with pure TiO2 particles that can easily form block product. In contrast, MOFs usually provide a rigid scaffold and possess chromophoric sensitizers serving as a "lantern," which results in the transformation of a large number of photons per unit volume from MOFs to TiO2, thus increasing the quantity of absorbed photons and enhancing the photocatalytic effect.
